awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Highly mismatched GaSb-GaAs thin film multijunction solar cells
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract: 
Non-Technical:
Rochester Institute of Technology and University of California Los Angeles propose to demonstrate a highly mismatched, Sb-based multi-junction solar cell with low defect density and optimal bandgaps, with efficiency over 50%. A novel growth technique known as interfacial misfit array will be used to develop the proposed solar cell devices. These devices would be capable of revolutionary advances in efficiency and perhaps the eventual possibility of transferring the high efficiency III-V technology to a low cost Si substrate. The proposed work will significantly reduce multi-junction solar cell cost and at the same time increase energy conversion efficiency. As well, the proposed material growth methods can have potential impact on areas such as detectors, lasers and memory devices.  This work will also support the development of educational activities at multiple levels.  Both graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in leading-edge materials engineering and device physics.  As well, both principle investigators will be involved in high school student summer mentoring in their laboratories, through a series of lectures and demonstrations involving the relationship between materials and solar energy conversion.  
Technical:
The technical aim of this proposal is to gain access to near optimal band gaps for a five junction solar cells by integrating Sb-based materials into the lattice matched InGaP2/GaAs technology using the GaSb interfacial misfit growth technique.  Interfacial misfit growth will allow for the lattice-mismatched growth of high quality GaSb on GaAs without the need for a complex and growth intensive step-grade buffer layer. Proposed devices will be comprised of lattice matched (Al)InGaP2, AlGaAs and GaAs as the top three cells, a single interfacial misfit transition and lattice matched 1.1 eV AlGaSb and 0.73 eV GaSb as the bottom two cells. Team members have already demonstrated the interfacial misfit growth of GaSb, which allows them to achieve the lattice-mismatched growth of high quality materials on GaAs, without the need for a complex and growth intensive step-grade buffer layer. In the first year, AlGaSb on GaSb/GaAs templates and InGaP on GaAs substrates along with required tunnel junctions will be developed, with the aim of understanding of optical and electrical properties. In the second and third years, the proposed three junction and five junction solar cells will be developed.  All of the steps will be supported by detailed materials characterization as well as physics-based device simulations, to optimize the device design and imporve the predictiave capabilites for Sb-based optoelectronics devices.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project was aimed to demonstrate the potential for a highly mismatched, Sb-based multi-junction (MJ) solar cell with low defect density and optimal bandgaps. We gain access to near optimal band gaps for a five junction solar cells by integrating Sb-based materials into the standard InGaP2/GaAs technology using the GaSb interfacial misfit (IMF) growth technique pioneered by our team members. IMF growth allowed us to achieve the lattice-mismatched (LMM) growth of high-quality GaSb on GaAs without the need for complex and growth intensive step-grade buffer layers. 

Specifically, in collaboration with UCLA, RIT has deepened the understanding of sidewall and passivation issues with GaSb solar cells and provided insight and solutions to many of the problems with IMF based GaSb solar cells. One of the major issues with the IMF cells is still the relatively high threading dislocation density(TDD), which affects the cell Voc as well as the shunt resistance. We have demonstrated an ~1% efficient (AM1.5) GaSb solar cell on GaAs using IMF, with a Voc slightly more than 100 mV. While clearly limited due to TDD in the 107 per sq. cm range, this device would be capable to support device operation as the bottom cell in 3-junction InGaP/GaAs/GaSb device, especially under concentration. 

Additionally, using the RIT metal organic chemical vapor depostion (MOCVD) system, which is a lower cost and industrially relevant solar cell manufacturing technique, we have shown that GaSb solar cells can be grown both on GaSb and on GaAs using IFM. This is important as it opensup device growth to the scalable and lower cost MOCVD tool. Our results by MOCVD for both the control and IMF cells compare very favorably or exceed MBE devices, and in the case of the thicker buffer IMF devices actually exceed our prior results, with a 2.2% efficiency (AM1.5) GaSb IMF solar cell on GaAs.We have also optimized for the effects of the GaSb buffer thickness and precursor type. The buffers thickness shows a clear trend to reduce TDD (as is well known in the metamorphic community). The effects of GaSb buffer layer thickness on device performance were quantified through extraction of threading dislocation density from measured EQE and light J-V data. A supplemental method to GaSb buffer thickness using a strained AlSb interlayer successfully reduced TDD in grown devices equivalent to a GaSb layer 23 times the AlSb thickness. Finally the gallium precursor used for n- and p-type materials in homoepitaxial devices was investigated, resulting in the best material with trimethylgallium doped with Te for the n-type emitter and triethylgallium doped with Zn for the p-type base.

Finally, it was shown that a benefit of the GaSb method over the incumbent metamorphic technology would be that additional metamorphic grades would not be necessary when adding lower bandgap 4th or 5th junctions, as once we transition to the Sb system using a single IMF, there are multiple lattice matched Sb-based materials with the necessary bandgaps.  In a modeled multijunction solar cell using GaSb as the bottom juction, this device gave an overall efficiency of 33.1 % under AM1.5g illumination, an approximate 2% absolute improvement over a similar devcie based on a Ge bottom junction.  It should be noted that this design still does not use the optimal bottom junction bandgap of 1 eV to make it a competitive replacement for the IMM design. This design can be improved upon by the integration of a 1 eV, AlₓGa₁₋ₓSb IMF junction, increasing the VOC of the bottom cell and increasing the efficiency ofthe triple junction.

 


Last Modified: 07/08/2021
Modified by: Seth M Hubbard

por.por_txt_cntn:
This project was aimed to demonstrate the potential for a highly mismatched, Sb-based multi-junction (MJ) solar cell with low defect density and optimal bandgaps. We gain access to near optimal band gaps for a five junction solar cells by integrating Sb-based materials into the standard InGaP2/GaAs technology using the GaSb interfacial misfit (IMF) growth technique pioneered by our team members. IMF growth allowed us to achieve the lattice-mismatched (LMM) growth of high-quality GaSb on GaAs without the need for complex and growth intensive step-grade buffer layers. 

Specifically, in collaboration with UCLA, RIT has deepened the understanding of sidewall and passivation issues with GaSb solar cells and provided insight and solutions to many of the problems with IMF based GaSb solar cells. One of the major issues with the IMF cells is still the relatively high threading dislocation density(TDD), which affects the cell Voc as well as the shunt resistance. We have demonstrated an ~1% efficient (AM1.5) GaSb solar cell on GaAs using IMF, with a Voc slightly more than 100 mV. While clearly limited due to TDD in the 107 per sq. cm range, this device would be capable to support device operation as the bottom cell in 3-junction InGaP/GaAs/GaSb device, especially under concentration. 

Additionally, using the RIT metal organic chemical vapor depostion (MOCVD) system, which is a lower cost and industrially relevant solar cell manufacturing technique, we have shown that GaSb solar cells can be grown both on GaSb and on GaAs using IFM. This is important as it opensup device growth to the scalable and lower cost MOCVD tool. Our results by MOCVD for both the control and IMF cells compare very favorably or exceed MBE devices, and in the case of the thicker buffer IMF devices actually exceed our prior results, with a 2.2% efficiency (AM1.5) GaSb IMF solar cell on GaAs.We have also optimized for the effects of the GaSb buffer thickness and precursor type. The buffers thickness shows a clear trend to reduce TDD (as is well known in the metamorphic community). The effects of GaSb buffer layer thickness on device performance were quantified through extraction of threading dislocation density from measured EQE and light J-V data. A supplemental method to GaSb buffer thickness using a strained AlSb interlayer successfully reduced TDD in grown devices equivalent to a GaSb layer 23 times the AlSb thickness. Finally the gallium precursor used for n- and p-type materials in homoepitaxial devices was investigated, resulting in the best material with trimethylgallium doped with Te for the n-type emitter and triethylgallium doped with Zn for the p-type base.

Finally, it was shown that a benefit of the GaSb method over the incumbent metamorphic technology would be that additional metamorphic grades would not be necessary when adding lower bandgap 4th or 5th junctions, as once we transition to the Sb system using a single IMF, there are multiple lattice matched Sb-based materials with the necessary bandgaps.  In a modeled multijunction solar cell using GaSb as the bottom juction, this device gave an overall efficiency of 33.1 % under AM1.5g illumination, an approximate 2% absolute improvement over a similar devcie based on a Ge bottom junction.  It should be noted that this design still does not use the optimal bottom junction bandgap of 1 eV to make it a competitive replacement for the IMM design. This design can be improved upon by the integration of a 1 eV, AlₓGa₁₋ₓSb IMF junction, increasing the VOC of the bottom cell and increasing the efficiency ofthe triple junction.

 

					Last Modified: 07/08/2021

					Submitted by: Seth M Hubbard
